SEARCH
Package java.net_modified

Class HttpURLConnection

java.lang.Object
java.net.URLConnection
java.net_modified.HttpURLConnection
public abstract class HttpURLConnection extends URLConnection
This class represents an HTTP-specific implementation of a URLConnection that provides methods for interacting with resources via HTTP. It supports features such as handling HTTP requests and responses.

Each HttpURLConnection instance is designed to handle a single HTTP request, although the underlying network connection to the HTTP server may be reused by other instances. Closing the InputStream or OutputStream associated with the HttpURLConnection may release network resources, but will not affect shared persistent connections. Calling disconnect() may close the underlying socket if no other connections are using it.

The behavior of HTTP connections can be controlled via system properties, such as proxy settings and miscellaneous HTTP settings.

Constructor Usage

HttpURLConnection is an abstract class, and instances of this class are typically obtained by calling URL.openConnection() on a URL object that uses the HTTP protocol. For example:

 URL url = new URL("http://www.example.com");
 HttpURLConnection httpConn = (HttpURLConnection) url.openConnection();

This will create an instance of a concrete subclass of HttpURLConnection, depending on the protocol handler available in the environment.

Security Considerations

If a security manager is installed, the caller must have the appropriate permissions to open a connection. The caller needs either:

  • A "connect" SocketPermission for the host/port combination of the destination URL.
  • A URLPermission that allows the request.

If automatic redirection is enabled, the caller must also possess the necessary permissions to connect to the redirected host/URL.

Note: This class is not thread-safe. Each instance should be used by one thread at a time.

Since:
1.1
See Also:
  • HttpURLConnection.disconnect()

  • Field Details

    • method

      protected String method
      The HTTP method used for the request (e.g., "GET", "POST", "PUT", etc.).

      By default, this is set to "GET". This field determines which HTTP method will be sent in the request. Valid values include standard HTTP methods such as "GET", "POST", "PUT", and "DELETE". Other custom methods may also be supported by the server.

      Note: The method must be set before establishing the connection. After the request is sent, modifying this value will have no effect.

      See Also:
      • setRequestMethod(String)

    • chunkLength

      protected int chunkLength
      The chunk-length to be used when the request body is sent using chunked encoding.

      A value of -1 indicates that chunked encoding is disabled. When chunked encoding is enabled, the request body is split into smaller chunks, and each chunk is sent separately. This allows the body to be sent without knowing its size beforehand.

      Important: This value must be set before the request is initiated, and changing it after the request is started will have no effect.

      Use this option for sending large bodies where the size is not known in advance.

      Since:
      1.5
      See Also:
      • setChunkedStreamingMode(int)

    • fixedContentLength

      protected int fixedContentLength
      The fixed content-length in bytes for output when using fixed-length streaming mode.

      A value of -1 means that fixed-length streaming mode is disabled. When enabled, the client sends the exact number of bytes specified. This can be more efficient when the size of the request body is known in advance.

      Note: It is recommended to use fixedContentLengthLong instead of this field, as it allows for larger content lengths to be set. Changing this field after initiating the connection will not affect the current request.

      Since:
      1.5
      See Also:
      • setFixedLengthStreamingMode(int)

    • fixedContentLengthLong

      protected long fixedContentLengthLong
      The fixed content-length in bytes for output when using fixed-length streaming mode.

      A value of -1 means that fixed-length streaming mode is disabled. This field supports content lengths larger than those allowed by fixedContentLength. When enabled, the client sends the exact number of bytes specified in the request.

      Using fixed-length streaming can improve performance by allowing the connection to be reused, but it requires knowing the size of the request body in advance.

      Since:
      1.7
      See Also:
      • setFixedLengthStreamingMode(long)

    • responseCode

      protected int responseCode
      An int representing the three digit HTTP Status-Code.
      • 1xx: Informational
      • 2xx: Success
      • 3xx: Redirection
      • 4xx: Client Error
      • 5xx: Server Error

    • responseMessage

      protected String responseMessage
      The HTTP response message.

    • instanceFollowRedirects

      protected boolean instanceFollowRedirects
      If true, the protocol will automatically follow redirects. If false, the protocol will not automatically follow redirects.

      This field is set by the setInstanceFollowRedirects method. Its value is returned by the getInstanceFollowRedirects method.

      Its default value is based on the value of the static followRedirects at HttpURLConnection construction time.

      See Also:
      • HttpURLConnection.setInstanceFollowRedirects(boolean)
      • HttpURLConnection.getInstanceFollowRedirects()
      • HttpURLConnection.setFollowRedirects(boolean)

    • HTTP_OK

      public static final int HTTP_OK
      HTTP Status-Code 200: OK.

      The request has succeeded. The meaning of the success depends on the HTTP method: GET: The resource has been fetched and is transmitted in the message body. POST: The resource describing the result of the action is transmitted in the message body.

      See Also:

  • Method Details

    • setAuthenticator

      public void setAuthenticator(Authenticator auth)
      Supplies an Authenticator to be used when authentication is requested through the HTTP protocol for this HttpURLConnection. If no authenticator is supplied, the default authenticator will be used.
      Parameters:
      auth - The Authenticator that should be used by this HttpURLConnection.
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - if setting an Authenticator is not supported by the underlying implementation.
      IllegalStateException - if URLConnection is already connected.
      NullPointerException - if the supplied auth is null.
      Since:
      9

    • getHeaderFieldKey

      public String getHeaderFieldKey(int n)
      Returns the key of the HTTP header field at the specified index n. The 0th header field may be treated as the HTTP status line, in which case this method will return null for n = 0.

      Usage Example:

      
 HttpURLConnection httpConn = (HttpURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 httpConn.setRequestMethod("GET");
 httpConn.connect();

 String headerKey = httpConn.getHeaderFieldKey(1);  // Get key of the 1st header field
 if (headerKey != null) {
     System.out.println("Header Key: " + headerKey);
 } else {
     System.out.println("No header key found at index 1.");
 }
      Overrides:
      getHeaderFieldKey in class URLConnection
      Parameters:
      n - the index of the header field, where n >= 0.
      Returns:
      the key for the nth header field, or null if no key exists at the specified index.
      See Also:
      • URLConnection.getHeaderField(int)
      • HttpURLConnection.getHeaderField(int)

    • setFixedLengthStreamingMode

      public void setFixedLengthStreamingMode(int contentLength)
      Enables streaming of an HTTP request body without internal buffering when the content length is known in advance and does not exceed the maximum value that can be represented by a 32-bit integer. For larger content lengths, use setFixedLengthStreamingMode(long).

      An exception will be thrown if the application attempts to write more data than the indicated content length, or if the OutputStream is closed before the specified amount is written.

      When output streaming is enabled, authentication and redirection cannot be handled automatically. A HttpRetryException will be thrown if authentication or redirection is required and the response cannot be read successfully. This exception provides details about the error encountered.

      This method must be called before the URLConnection is connected. Once connected, the content length cannot be changed.

      Note: If the content length exceeds the maximum value representable by a 32-bit integer, use setFixedLengthStreamingMode(long) to accommodate larger sizes.

      Parameters:
      contentLength - the length of the content to be sent, in bytes. This must be a non-negative integer not exceeding the maximum value of a 32-bit signed integer.
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException - if the URLConnection is already connected or if a different streaming mode is already enabled.
      IllegalArgumentException - if a content length less than zero is specified.
      Since:
      1.5
      See Also:
      • setFixedLengthStreamingMode(long)
      • setChunkedStreamingMode(int)

    • setFixedLengthStreamingMode

      public void setFixedLengthStreamingMode(long contentLength)
      Enables streaming of an HTTP request body without internal buffering when the content length is known in advance and exceeds the maximum value that can be represented by a 32-bit integer. This method should be used when the content length is greater than 2,147,483,647 bytes (2 GB).

      An exception will be thrown if the application attempts to write more data than the indicated content length, or if the OutputStream is closed before the specified amount is written.

      When output streaming is enabled, authentication and redirection cannot be handled automatically. A HttpRetryException will be thrown if authentication or redirection is required and the response cannot be read successfully. This exception provides details about the error encountered.

      This method must be called before the URLConnection is connected. Once connected, the content length cannot be changed.

      Note: Use this method for content lengths that exceed the 2 GB limit of setFixedLengthStreamingMode(int).

      Parameters:
      contentLength - the length of the content to be sent, in bytes. This must be a non-negative long value.
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException - if the URLConnection is already connected or if a different streaming mode is already enabled.
      IllegalArgumentException - if a content length less than zero is specified.
      Since:
      1.7
      See Also:
      • setFixedLengthStreamingMode(int)
      • setChunkedStreamingMode(int)

    • setChunkedStreamingMode

      public void setChunkedStreamingMode(int chunklen)
      Enables streaming of an HTTP request body using chunked transfer encoding, without internal buffering, when the content length is not known in advance. This method sets the chunk size for each chunk of data sent to the server.

      Chunked transfer encoding breaks the request body into smaller chunks, each prefixed with its size in hexadecimal and followed by two CRLFs (carriage return, line feed). This mode is particularly useful for dynamically generated content or large requests where the content length cannot be predetermined. However, not all HTTP servers support chunked transfer encoding.

      Important Notes:

      • Chunked streaming mode must be enabled before the connection is established using URLConnection.connect().
      • When this mode is enabled, automatic handling of authentication and redirection is disabled. If authentication or redirection is required during the request, a HttpRetryException will be thrown.
      • If the specified chunklen is less than or equal to 5 bytes (including the chunk header), a default chunk size of 4096 bytes will be used.

      Example Usage:

      
 HttpURLConnection httpConn = (HttpURLConnection) new URL("https://example.com").openConnection();
 httpConn.setChunkedStreamingMode(1024); // Set chunk size to 1024 bytes
 httpConn.setRequestMethod("POST");
 httpConn.setDoOutput(true);
 OutputStream outputStream = httpConn.getOutputStream();
 // Write request body in chunks

      Default Behavior: If chunklen is not specified or is invalid, a default chunk size of 4096 bytes (including the chunk header and payload) will be used.

      Exceptions:

      • IllegalStateException is thrown if the connection has already been established or if another streaming mode (such as fixed-length) is enabled.
      Parameters:
      chunklen - The number of bytes for each chunk, including the chunk size header and payload. Must be greater than 5 bytes, otherwise the default value is used.
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException - if the connection has already been established or if another streaming mode is already set.
      Since:
      1.5
      See Also:
      • setFixedLengthStreamingMode(int)
      • HttpRetryException

    • getHeaderField

      public String getHeaderField(int n)
      Returns the value of the HTTP header field at the specified index n. This method allows access to HTTP header values returned by the server in the response. Header fields are indexed starting from 0, where some implementations may treat the 0th field as the status line (e.g., "HTTP/1.1 200 OK").

      This method can be used in conjunction with getHeaderFieldKey(int) to iterate over all the headers in the HTTP response. For example, you can retrieve both the key and value of each header by using the two methods together in a loop.

      If the header at the specified index does not exist, this method returns null. It also returns null if the index is out of bounds.

      Usage Example:

      
 HttpURLConnection httpConn = (HttpURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 httpConn.setRequestMethod("GET");
 httpConn.connect();
 
 // Iterate over all headers
 for (int i = 0;; i++) {
     String headerKey = httpConn.getHeaderFieldKey(i);
     String headerValue = httpConn.getHeaderField(i);
     if (headerKey == null && headerValue == null) {
         break; // No more headers
     }
     System.out.println(headerKey + ": " + headerValue);
 }
      Overrides:
      getHeaderField in class URLConnection
      Parameters:
      n - the index of the header field, where n >= 0.
      Returns:
      the value of the nth header field, or null if the header does not exist or if the index is out of bounds.
      See Also:
      • HttpURLConnection.getHeaderFieldKey(int)
      • URLConnection.getHeaderField(int)

    • setFollowRedirects

      public static void setFollowRedirects(boolean set)
      Sets whether HTTP redirects (requests with response codes in the 3xx range) should be automatically followed by instances of this class.

      By default, this setting is enabled (true). When disabled (false), the connection will return the 3xx status code, and it will be the responsibility of the application to manage redirection.

      Important Notes:

      • This setting applies to all HttpURLConnection instances created after the change.
      • Applets cannot modify this setting.
      • If a security manager is present, checkSetFactory() will be called to ensure the change is allowed. A SecurityException will be thrown if permission is denied.

      Example Usage:

      
 // Disable automatic redirects
 HttpURLConnection.setFollowRedirects(false);
 
 HttpURLConnection connection = (HttpURLConnection) new URL("https://example.com").openConnection();
 connection.connect();
 
 int responseCode = connection.getResponseCode();
 if (responseCode == HttpURLConnection.HTTP_MOVED_TEMP) {
     // Handle the redirection manually
     String newLocation = connection.getHeaderField("Location");
     System.out.println("Redirected to: " + newLocation);
 }

      This method changes the default redirection behavior for all connections. For controlling redirects on a per-connection basis, use setInstanceFollowRedirects(boolean).

      Parameters:
      set - a boolean specifying whether to follow HTTP redirects. Default is true.
      Throws:
      SecurityException - if a security manager exists and denies the operation via checkSetFactory().
      See Also:
      • SecurityManager.checkSetFactory()
      • getFollowRedirects()
      • setInstanceFollowRedirects(boolean)

    • getFollowRedirects

      public static boolean getFollowRedirects()
      Returns a boolean indicating whether HTTP redirects (3xx responses) should be automatically followed by the current connection. If redirects are followed, the client will automatically handle 3xx status codes by making additional requests to the new location provided in the response's "Location" header.

      This is a global setting for all HTTP connections and affects all instances of HttpURLConnection. The default value is true, meaning redirects are automatically followed unless explicitly disabled.

      Usage Example:

      
 boolean followRedirects = HttpURLConnection.getFollowRedirects();
 if (followRedirects) {
     System.out.println("Redirects are automatically followed.");
 } else {
     System.out.println("Redirects are not automatically followed.");
 }
      Returns:
      true if HTTP redirects are automatically followed, false if they are not.
      See Also:
      • HttpURLConnection.setFollowRedirects(boolean)

    • setInstanceFollowRedirects

      public void setInstanceFollowRedirects(boolean followRedirects)
      Configures whether HTTP redirects (requests with response code 3xx) should be automatically followed by this HttpURLConnection instance.

      When set to true, this instance will automatically follow HTTP redirects. When set to false, the instance will not follow redirects and the client code must handle redirect responses manually. This setting affects only the current HttpURLConnection instance and does not alter the behavior of other instances or the default behavior of the class.

      Behavior and Scope:

      • This method's setting applies only to the current instance of HttpURLConnection. It does not affect other instances of HttpURLConnection, even if they are created from the same URL or use the same connection factory.
      • To affect redirect behavior globally, use the static method setFollowRedirects(boolean). This static method sets the default redirect-following behavior for all instances of HttpURLConnection created thereafter.
      • Changing this setting on an instance does not retroactively affect connections that were already established or other instances created prior to this change.

      Usage Example:

      
 HttpURLConnection connection = (HttpURLConnection) new URL("https://example.com").openConnection();
 connection.setInstanceFollowRedirects(false); // Disable automatic redirect following
 // Handle redirects manually if needed

      Important Notes:

      • Ensure this method is called before establishing a connection to apply the desired redirect behavior.
      • For global redirect behavior settings affecting all instances, use setFollowRedirects(boolean).
      Parameters:
      followRedirects - a boolean indicating whether HTTP redirects should be automatically followed by this instance. true to follow redirects, false to handle them manually.
      Since:
      1.3
      See Also:
      • getInstanceFollowRedirects()
      • setFollowRedirects(boolean)

    • getInstanceFollowRedirects

      public boolean getInstanceFollowRedirects()
      Returns the value of this HttpURLConnection's instanceFollowRedirects field, which indicates whether this specific connection instance will automatically follow HTTP redirects (3xx responses). This setting affects only this instance, not the global setting.

      By default, the value is inherited from the global setting. You can control it for this instance using setInstanceFollowRedirects(boolean).

      Usage Example:

      
 HttpURLConnection httpConn = (HttpURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 boolean followRedirects = httpConn.getInstanceFollowRedirects();
 System.out.println("Instance follows redirects: " + followRedirects);
      Returns:
      true if this instance will follow redirects automatically, false otherwise.
      Since:
      1.3
      See Also:
      • HttpURLConnection.instanceFollowRedirects
      • HttpURLConnection.setInstanceFollowRedirects(boolean)

    • setRequestMethod

      public void setRequestMethod(String method) throws ProtocolException
      Sets the HTTP request method to the specified method (eg. "GET", "POST", "HEAD", "OPTIONS", "PUT", "DELETE", "TRACE"). The method must be set before the connection is established by calling URLConnection.connect(), or a ProtocolException will be thrown.

      By default, the request method is "GET". This method cannot be called after writing to the output stream or receiving a response from the server.

      Allowed HTTP methods:

      • GET
      • POST
      • HEAD
      • OPTIONS
      • PUT
      • DELETE
      • TRACE

      Usage Notes:

      • This method must be called before the connection is established using connect() or before writing to the request body (for methods like "POST").
      • This method is not thread-safe. If multiple threads access the same instance of HttpURLConnection, external synchronization is required.
      • Setting the method to "TRACE" requires a special security permission: allowHttpTrace.

      Usage Example:

      
 URL url = new URL("https://example.com");
 HttpURLConnection httpConn = (HttpURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 
 // Set the request method to POST
 httpConn.setRequestMethod("POST");
 
 // Send POST data
 httpConn.setDoOutput(true);
 OutputStream os = httpConn.getOutputStream();
 os.write("param1=value1&param2=value2".getBytes());
 os.flush();
 os.close();
 
 // Read the response
 int responseCode = httpConn.getResponseCode();
 System.out.println("Response Code: " + responseCode);
 httpConn.disconnect();
      Parameters:
      method - the HTTP request method to be set (e.g., "GET", "POST").
      Throws:
      ProtocolException - if the method cannot be reset after connecting, or if the requested method is invalid for HTTP.
      IllegalArgumentException - if the specified method is null.
      SecurityException - if a security manager is set and the method is "TRACE" but the "allowHttpTrace" NetPermission is not granted.
      See Also:
      • getRequestMethod()

    • getRequestMethod

      public String getRequestMethod()
      Returns the HTTP request method used by this HttpURLConnection instance. Common methods include "GET", "POST", "PUT", "DELETE", etc.

      Usage Example:

      
 HttpURLConnection httpConn = (HttpURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 String requestMethod = httpConn.getRequestMethod();
 System.out.println("Request Method: " + requestMethod);
      Returns:
      the HTTP request method as a String.
      See Also:
      • HttpURLConnection.setRequestMethod(String)

    • getResponseCode

      public int getResponseCode() throws IOException
      Returns the HTTP status code from the response message. For example, for the following status lines:
      • HTTP/1.0 200 OK returns 200
      • HTTP/1.0 401 Unauthorized returns 401
      If the response is not valid HTTP, or no status code can be discerned, this method returns -1.

      Usage Example:

      
 HttpURLConnection httpConn = (HttpURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 try {
     int responseCode = httpConn.getResponseCode();
     System.out.println("Response Code: " + responseCode);
 } catch (IOException e) {
     e.printStackTrace();  // Handle potential connection error
 }
      Returns:
      the HTTP status code, or -1 if no valid status code is found.
      Throws:
      IOException - if an error occurs while connecting to the server.
      See Also:
      • HttpURLConnection.getResponseMessage()

    • getResponseMessage

      public String getResponseMessage() throws IOException
      Returns the HTTP response message returned by the server, which provides a textual description of the status code. For example:
      • HTTP/1.0 200 OK returns "OK"
      • HTTP/1.0 404 Not Found returns "Not Found"

      This method should be called after establishing a connection and receiving a response from the server. It is generally used in conjunction with getResponseCode() to interpret the server's response. The response code provides the numerical status, while the response message provides the textual description.

      If no valid response message can be determined (e.g., if the response is not a valid HTTP response), this method returns null.

      Usage Example:

      
 HttpURLConnection httpConn = (HttpURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 try {
     httpConn.connect(); // Ensure the connection is established
     int responseCode = httpConn.getResponseCode();
     String responseMessage = httpConn.getResponseMessage();
     System.out.println("Response Code: " + responseCode);
     System.out.println("Response Message: " + responseMessage);
 } catch (IOException e) {
     e.printStackTrace();  // Handle potential connection error
 }
      Returns:
      the HTTP response message, or null if no valid message is found.
      Throws:
      IOException - if an error occurs while connecting to the server.
      See Also:
      • getResponseCode()

    • getHeaderFieldDate

      public long getHeaderFieldDate(String name, long defaultValue)
      Returns the value of the specified header field parsed as a date. The result is the number of milliseconds since January 1, 1970 GMT. If the field is missing or cannot be parsed as a date, the provided Default value is returned.

      Usage Example:

      
 HttpURLConnection httpConn = (HttpURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 long date = httpConn.getHeaderFieldDate("Last-Modified", System.currentTimeMillis());
 if (date != 0) {
     System.out.println("Last-Modified: " + new Date(date));
 } else {
     System.out.println("No valid Last-Modified header.");
 }
      Overrides:
      getHeaderFieldDate in class URLConnection
      Parameters:
      name - the name of the header field.
      Default - the default value to return if the field is missing or malformed.
      Returns:
      the parsed date value in milliseconds since January 1, 1970 GMT, or the Default value if the field is missing or invalid.
      See Also:
      • URLConnection.getHeaderFieldDate(String, long)

    • disconnect

      public abstract void disconnect()
      Terminates the connection to the HTTP server and indicates that no further requests are expected in the near future. Calling disconnect() will close the underlying connection if no other requests are currently sharing the same persistent connection.

      Once disconnect() is called, this HttpURLConnection instance cannot be reused for additional requests. However, it will not affect other instances that may be using the same underlying connection, as connection pooling is managed transparently.

      This method should be called when the caller is finished using the connection to release network resources efficiently. It is especially important to call disconnect() in environments with limited resources (e.g., mobile devices or embedded systems).

      Note: This method is not thread-safe. If multiple threads are using the same HttpURLConnection, care must be taken to avoid calling disconnect() while other threads are performing network operations on it.

      Usage Example:

      
 URL url = new URL("http://www.example.com");
 HttpURLConnection httpConn = (HttpURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 try {
     httpConn.setRequestMethod("GET");
     InputStream responseStream = httpConn.getInputStream();
     // Process the response...
 } finally {
     httpConn.disconnect();  // Always disconnect when done
 }
      See Also:
      • URLConnection.connect()
      • URLConnection.getInputStream()
      • URLConnection.getOutputStream()

    • usingProxy

      public abstract boolean usingProxy()
      Determines whether this HttpURLConnection is using a proxy.

      This method returns true if the connection is known to be routed through a proxy server, either via an explicit proxy configuration (e.g., set through system properties such as http.proxyHost and http.proxyPort) or detected automatically. It returns false if no proxy is used or if it cannot conclusively determine whether the connection is proxied.

      Usage Notes:

      • This method may return false in cases where the proxy settings are not accessible to the current instance or when the proxy is determined dynamically at runtime (e.g., using a ProxySelector).
      • This method only applies to HTTP proxies and may not reflect the use of other proxy types such as SOCKS proxies.

      Example Usage:

      
 HttpURLConnection connection = (HttpURLConnection) new URL("https://example.com").openConnection();
 boolean isUsingProxy = connection.usingProxy();
 if (isUsingProxy) {
     System.out.println("The connection is using a proxy.");
 } else {
     System.out.println("The connection is not using a proxy.");
 }
      Returns:
      true if the connection is routed through a proxy, false otherwise or if undetermined.
      See Also:
      • Proxy
      • ProxySelector

    • getPermission

      public Permission getPermission() throws IOException
      Returns a SocketPermission object representing the permission required to connect to the destination host and port. This permission is typically checked by security managers to determine if the connection is allowed.

      If an error occurs while determining the permission, an IOException is thrown.

      Usage Example:

      
 HttpURLConnection httpConn = (HttpURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 try {
     Permission permission = httpConn.getPermission();
     System.out.println("Permission: " + permission);
 } catch (IOException e) {
     e.printStackTrace();  // Handle potential error
 }
      Overrides:
      getPermission in class URLConnection
      Returns:
      a SocketPermission object representing the necessary permission to connect to the destination host and port.
      Throws:
      IOException - if an error occurs while computing the permission.
      See Also:
      • SocketPermission
      • URLConnection.getPermission()

    • getErrorStream

      public InputStream getErrorStream()
      Returns the error stream if the connection failed but the server still sent useful data. For example, when an HTTP server responds with a 404 status code (which may cause a FileNotFoundException during URLConnection.connect()), the server might still send an HTML page with information or suggestions. This method allows access to such error data.

      Calling this method does not initiate a new connection. It only returns an error stream if the connection has been established and the server encountered an error while processing the request, but still sent useful error data. If no error occurred, the server did not send any error data, or the connection was not made, this method returns null.

      Usage Example:

      
 HttpURLConnection httpConn = (HttpURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 try {
     httpConn.setRequestMethod("GET");
     InputStream errorStream = httpConn.getErrorStream();
     if (errorStream != null) {
         // Process the error stream, e.g., log it or display it to the user
     }
 } finally {
     httpConn.disconnect();
 }
      Returns:
      an error stream if the server sent error data, or null if there are no errors, the connection was not established, or the server did not provide any error data.
      See Also:
      • URLConnection.getInputStream()
      • URLConnection.connect()
      • HttpURLConnection.disconnect()
